blog.title: The 45,000‑Rupiah Miracle
blog.description: How Bali quietly makes family life feel easy
blog.body:
By Eric

Some mornings in Bali start with a soundtrack you didn’t know you needed.

A rooster somewhere in the distance. The soft clink of temple bells. A scooter humming past slowly—less “rush hour,” more “someone’s going to buy fruit.” Incense drifting in from a tiny offering placed neatly on the edge of a driveway. My kids outside, barefoot, already inventing a game out of sticks and leaves and whatever the jungle decides to contribute that day.

It’s the kind of scene people fly across the world to witness for a week.

And yet the thing that still surprises me most isn’t the beauty. It’s the convenience.

Because in the background of all that calm—rice fields flowing like green water, the jungle breathing, the space to actually hear yourself think—Bali has quietly built something that makes daily family life feel… manageable. Even comfortable. Sometimes weirdly effortless.

The number that captures it best is 45,000 rupiah.

That’s the delivery fee I pay for groceries when I don’t want to turn the day into a traffic mission. Less than $3 for someone to bring what my family needs right to our door.

It sounds like a small detail. It’s not.

The best Bali days don’t begin in a car

When families imagine moving to Bali, they picture the big things first:

Nature

Community

A slower pace

A healthier rhythm for their kids

All true.

But the part you only learn by living here is that your day-to-day happiness often depends on the small things: How easy is it to get what you need? How often do errands hijack your schedule? How much time do you spend stuck in transit instead of actually living?

That’s where Bali has been a joyful surprise for me.

If I need something—anything from household essentials to random “we ran out of that and my kids will absolutely notice” items—I open Tokopedia or Shopee, search, tap, and it’s handled. What still amazes me is how often it’s more affordable than America, and how reliably it just works.

It’s not flashy. It’s just… supportive.

And for a family, support is everything.

“Western groceries” without the weekly expedition

I still like going to big grocery stores sometimes. There’s something satisfying about it—choosing, browsing, finding a new snack you didn’t know existed.

But I don’t want that to be my default rhythm. I don’t want “getting groceries” to be a project that consumes half a day and all my patience.

So for many of our staples—especially the “Western products” my family likes—I use online grocery services like Delta online.

And then that number shows up again:

Rp 45,000.

Not just a fee—more like a quiet life upgrade.

Because what that buys isn’t only delivery. It buys time. It buys energy. It buys the kind of afternoon where you’re not recovering from errands—you’re actually present for your kids.

Fresh vegetables that don’t require a plan

Then there’s the produce side of life, where Bali shines in its own way.

For vegetables, I use Bali Jiva.

There’s something deeply satisfying about waking up in a place with temples and rice fields and sunlight pouring in—then having crisp greens show up without you needing to navigate the day around it.

It’s one of those “pinch me” moments: you can live near nature without feeling cut off from the modern world.

(The main idea is the system: let delivery handle errands so your days stay calm.)

Ubud: incredible… and optional

Ubud is special. There are truly great restaurants there. The kind of place you go for a meal that feels like a celebration—without needing a special occasion.

But here’s the honest part: the traffic can be intense.

And what I’ve learned is that you don’t have to build your life around the busiest places to enjoy them. You can treat Ubud like a destination you visit when you want that experience—then come back to the version of Bali that feels like it was designed for families.

For us, that’s the area in and around Empathy School.

This is the Bali I didn’t just want to visit. This is the Bali I wanted my kids to grow inside of:

Flowing rice fields that change color with the season

Jungle edges that feel alive, not manicured

Space—real space—for kids to play

A sense of safety and peace that settles into your body

When you live somewhere like this, convenience isn’t about luxury. It’s about preserving the calm you came here for.

The real “Bali hack” for families

People sometimes ask what makes day-to-day life work here as a parent.

My answer is simple: don’t fight the island. Let it carry you.

Here’s what that looks like in our life:

Use Tokopedia + Shopee when you need “stuff” quickly and easily.

Use Delta online when you want groceries without a long outing.

Use Bali Jiva to keep vegetables fresh and effortless.

Go to Ubud for the magic—without making it your weekly commute.

Build your everyday life around nature, space, and calm—then let delivery handle the logistics.

This is how you get the best of both worlds: the Bali people dream about, plus the Bali that actually functions when you have kids and routines and real-life needs.

Why this feels so good

There’s a particular kind of joy that happens when you move somewhere beautiful and realize you don’t have to sacrifice practicality to enjoy it.

It’s not just that the kids are happier (though they are). It’s not just that the surroundings are stunning (they are).

It’s that your days stop being dominated by “life admin.”

Instead of spending your best hours in traffic, you spend them listening to the temple sounds drift through the morning. Watching your kids build something imaginative out of nothing. Walking near rice fields that look like they’ve been painted fresh overnight.

And somewhere in the middle of all that, a delivery arrives.

Groceries. Vegetables. The little things.

Handled.

That’s the 45,000‑rupiah miracle.

blog.title: Why I Feel So Safe Raising Kids in Bali
blog.description: When families talk to me about moving to Bali, “Is it safe?” is usually the first real question.
blog.body:
When families talk to me about moving to Bali, “Is it safe?” is usually the first real question.

I understand it. Safety isn’t a headline. It’s a daily feeling. It’s whether you can relax while your kids grow up. It’s whether ordinary life stays ordinary.

So instead of trying to convince you with big statements, I’ll just share what safety looks like in our family’s day-to-day life here—simple routines, small rules, and a community that makes it easy to exhale.

The Best Safety Upgrade We Made Was… Geography

Our house is near Empathy School.

That one detail changes everything.

It means my kids can walk to school. It means mornings don’t start with traffic and rushing and stress. It means the school isn’t a distant destination—it’s part of the neighborhood.

Most mornings, my two boys walk together. Sometimes I’m with them. Sometimes their mom is with them. Sometimes it’s just the two of them, heading down the lane with their backpacks and their own little conversations.

It’s one of those scenes that still makes me smile every time. It’s calm. It’s sweet. And for me, it’s a huge part of why Bali feels so safe: the place is built for real life, not constant guarding and managing.

The 6:00 PM Rule That Makes Everyone’s Life Easier

My older son is 12, which is the age where independence starts to arrive in steady waves.

He’ll often tell me he’s going to a friend’s house. My rule is straightforward:

You can go.

Tell me in advance.

Be home by 6:00 PM.

Sometimes he forgets to tell me ahead of time. He’s 12. It happens. But most of the time, he remembers.

And the 6:00 PM boundary works for a few practical reasons: the daylight fades quickly, it’s dinner time, and I don’t want another family to feel like they’re responsible for feeding my kid every night.

What I love most is how little “management” this requires. I don’t need a long explanation of where he’ll be every minute. I don’t need a detailed plan. He’s with friends. Sometimes he brings friends to our house, sometimes he’s at theirs.

It’s easy. It feels normal.

That’s the kind of safety parents are really looking for.

A Road That’s Not Built for Speed Helps More Than You’d Think

There’s a small detail between our home and the school that makes a big difference: the road isn’t especially friendly to fast cars.

It naturally slows things down. It’s more human-scale. That’s a big deal when you have kids walking around.

In many places, a parent’s worry is shaped by traffic more than anything else. Here, the environment itself encourages slower movement and more awareness. For walking children, that matters every single day.

The Dogs Are Part of the Neighborhood

Yes, there are dogs around. That’s common in Bali.

In our area, they’re not strangers. My kids know the dogs. I know the dogs. They feel like part of the neighborhood, not a threat.

There are also periodic vaccination drives in the community, which helps everyone feel more comfortable. And if something ever feels off, there’s usually a direct, human solution: talk to the neighbor who looks after that dog.

One of the most comforting things about Bali is that people are receptive. If you bring a concern respectfully, you’re usually met with respect in return.

Community Is a Kind of Security System

The Balinese community around us is warm and open. We get invited to temples and ceremonies and shared experiences. There’s a feeling of being included, not kept at arm’s length.

And that’s not just “nice.” It’s protective.

When you know your neighbors—and they know you—kids are more visible. People notice. People help. It’s not formal. It’s just how daily life works.

Safety is often created by relationship.

A Quick Story About the Police: Calm, Capable, and Close By

A while back, we donated money to help the local police build a radio tower so they could communicate more easily with one another. The school also has a channel on that network.

We’ve never needed to use it. But it’s there.

That matters to me—not because I expect emergencies, but because it’s reassuring to know the local systems are real and reachable.

When I visited the police station, I asked—mostly out of curiosity—if I could see the jail area. They showed me, and it was… dusty. Cobwebs and all.

I asked when they last used it.

Their answer was almost charming: the last “situation” was a very drunk farmer they couldn’t get home safely, so they let him sleep there for the night.

That was it.

Not dramatic. Not scary. Just a community handling a small human problem in a practical way.

Even the School Has Been Treated With Respect

One of the things I’m most grateful for is this: over the years, we haven’t experienced vandalism on campus. We haven’t had people breaking in and damaging the school.

That doesn’t mean nothing ever happens anywhere. It just reflects what we’ve lived: a strong baseline of respect for shared spaces, for children, and for the community.

What Safety Looks Like for Us, in Simple Terms

If I had to summarize the habits and conditions that make Bali feel so safe for our family, it would be these:

We live close enough to walk, so kids aren’t dependent on cars and long commutes.

We keep rules simple, like “tell us first” and “home by 6.”

The neighborhood moves at a slower pace, especially on the smaller roads.

There’s a sense of community presence, not isolation.

Local support is accessible, and people are responsive when you talk to them.

And maybe most importantly: the feeling of safety here isn’t something I have to work hard to create. It’s something the environment supports.

If You’re Considering Bali

If you’re thinking about moving your family here, I won’t tell you to ignore your questions. Ask them. Visit. Walk around the neighborhoods you might live in. Notice how your body feels during an ordinary morning.

In our life here—raising a 12-year-old and a five-year-old—Bali has felt peaceful, welcoming, and deeply safe.

And I don’t take that for granted.

—Eric (Founder, Empathy School)

- What does a typical day look like? (start/end time, indoor/outdoor balance, breaks)

- How do you keep kids hydrated and protected from sun?

### Staff quality

- Who are the adults on the ground each day? (teachers, facilitators, assistants)

- Who is the point of contact for parents?

### Communication

- How do you communicate with parents (WhatsApp, email, daily notes)?
- Will we get photos or updates—and how often?

- What exactly is included in the fee (meals, activities, transport)?

## Culture with kids (a calm, respectful approach)

This is **experience-based guidance**, not an official authority.
Culture differs by village and context. When in doubt: **ask**, follow local guidance, and stay humble.

### Before you go

- **Ask first:** “Is it okay for us to join/watch?”
- **Dress modestly** (especially for temples/ceremonies): covered shoulders, respectful clothing, and follow local expectations.
- **Keep it simple for kids:** short duration, clear boundaries, snacks/water.
- **Bring a small offering/donation** if your local community suggests it.

### During cultural moments

- **Follow the flow:** stand where others stand, wait when others wait.
- **Don’t treat it like a show:** avoid loud commentary, avoid directing kids like you’re filming.
- **Photos/video:** ask if it’s okay, and avoid filming people closely.
- **Kids first:** if your child is overwhelmed, step out quietly and return later.

### After

- **Debrief gently:** ask kids what they noticed, what felt different, what they liked.
- **Keep it relational:** the goal isn’t “understanding everything,” it’s learning how to be respectful guests.
